title: Why do some teachers take so long to put in grades? - Quora

response.answer_text: The other answers here are correct. I’m only going to add two more possibilities, both of which are true in my school: They’re waiting for students who didn’t turn in the work to turn it in. This way they can grade and comment on the whole pile at once. This is also why some teachers take a long time to return assignments. We don’t want to return a graded assignment when there are still students who haven’t done the assignment. It’s like handing out the right answers to their friends.If your​ school has an online gradebook that you or your parents can check any time, it doesn’t mean that the teacher uses just that gradebook. They may have a traditional paper gradebook that they use first. Then they input all of the grades online in one big sitting. There are a few reasons to do this, but I do it this way because it keeps students and parents from complaining about their grades every single day. I input grades online every few weeks, in big chunks. Then brace for a day of complaints, then move on with teaching.

While both of the answers here are pretty legitimate, I’ll add another few wrinkles to it. Subject matters: Multiple choice tests are easy. Heck, sometimes they even auto-posted in this day and age. Essays are the opposite.Time of year matters: At certain times of year, a great many other educational obligations loom. Towards the end of the year, teachers are often required to fill out lots of paperwork about student progress for special programs. That takes away from grading.Priorities: Ask me if I’d rather grade or spend time talking with my students, helping them work through a challenging assignment, or checking on their general well-being.Priorities, revisited: I love teaching. It’s my job and my passion. I love my family more. When I leave the school, I’m a father. I don’t teach, grade, or answer educational emails outside of the school day. I don’t apologize for that. I don’t even eat lunch with other teachers, so I don’t waste time at work. When I go home, though, I am focused on MY children, not yours.That last in particular may not be popular in some circles, but I don’t think many other folks would approve if their jobs forced them to ignore their families night after night. I’m well aware some people take jobs with that asterisk, and that’s fine for them. I didn’t, and I never hide that in interviews. Somehow I’m still being hired, so I guess my point of view there isn’t so radical after all.
